title: Assignment 1
text:
My first assignment has three parts:




RStudio Cloud demo presentation provides information about the usage and sharing of RStudio Cloud. RStudio Cloud is a cloud-based development environment designed primarily for educational purposes. Users can create projects, share them, and interact with students.
Highlights
-ğŸ¢ RStudio Cloud provides users with easy access to a specific educational environment.
-ğŸ“ You can collaborate in short-term activities by sharing a single project.
-ğŸ”„ You can enable students to continuously work on their projects by copying them.
-ğŸ‘€ You can assist and provide feedback to students by reviewing their projects.
-ğŸ’¡ You can provide a starting point for students and standardize learning materials using basic projects.






Creating a vector and performing vectorized operations in R
numbers <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
squared <- numbers^2
mean_value <- mean(numbers)
Creating a list and performing element-wise operations in Python
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
squared = [x**2 for x in numbers]
mean_value = sum(numbers) / len(numbers)



Using the dplyr package for data manipulation in R
library(dplyr)
df <- data.frame(x = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5), y = c(6, 7, 8, 9, 10))
result <- df %>% filter(x > 2) %>% select(y)
Using pandas for data manipulation in Python
import pandas as pd
df = pd.DataFrame({â€˜xâ€™: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], â€˜yâ€™: [6, 7, 8, 9, 10]})
result = df[df[â€˜xâ€™] > 2][â€˜yâ€™]



Loading the ggplot2 package in R
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) + geom_point()
# Importing the matplotlib library in Python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.scatter(df[â€˜xâ€™], df[â€˜yâ€™])
plt.show()




Install the â€œdslabsâ€ package (only need to install once)
#install.packages(â€œdslabsâ€)
#Load the â€œdslabsâ€ library
library(dslabs)
#Load the â€œna_exampleâ€ data
data(â€œna_exampleâ€)
#Print the â€œna_exampleâ€ data
print(na_example)
#Check for NAs and replace them with 1
na_check <- ifelse(is.na(na_example), 1, 0)
#Calculate the total number of NAs
sum_na <- sum(na_check)
sum_na # Total number of NAs
#Replace NAs with 0
without_na <- ifelse(is.na(na_example), 0, na_example)
#Calculate the updated number of NAs (should be 0)
updated_num_na <- sum(ifelse(is.na(without_na), 1, 0))
updated_num_na

title: Assignment 1
text:
Creating a vector and performing vectorized operations in R
numbers <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
squared <- numbers^2
mean_value <- mean(numbers)
Creating a list and performing element-wise operations in Python
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
squared = [x**2 for x in numbers]
mean_value = sum(numbers) / len(numbers)



Using the dplyr package for data manipulation in R
library(dplyr)
df <- data.frame(x = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5), y = c(6, 7, 8, 9, 10))
result <- df %>% filter(x > 2) %>% select(y)
Using pandas for data manipulation in Python
import pandas as pd
df = pd.DataFrame({â€˜xâ€™: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], â€˜yâ€™: [6, 7, 8, 9, 10]})
result = df[df[â€˜xâ€™] > 2][â€˜yâ€™]



Loading the ggplot2 package in R
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) + geom_point()
# Importing the matplotlib library in Python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.scatter(df[â€˜xâ€™], df[â€˜yâ€™])
plt.show()

title: Assignment 1
text:
Install the â€œdslabsâ€ package (only need to install once)
#install.packages(â€œdslabsâ€)
#Load the â€œdslabsâ€ library
library(dslabs)
#Load the â€œna_exampleâ€ data
data(â€œna_exampleâ€)
#Print the â€œna_exampleâ€ data
print(na_example)
#Check for NAs and replace them with 1
na_check <- ifelse(is.na(na_example), 1, 0)
#Calculate the total number of NAs
sum_na <- sum(na_check)
sum_na # Total number of NAs
#Replace NAs with 0
without_na <- ifelse(is.na(na_example), 0, na_example)
#Calculate the updated number of NAs (should be 0)
updated_num_na <- sum(ifelse(is.na(without_na), 1, 0))
updated_num_na
